item.title: By: Hendry
item.dc:creator: Hendry
item.description:
This is a common problem with Transcend Micro Solid State Drives. If you are running your Windows Operating System on one of these drives, you will get a super-fast startup time and application start time.
However, the OS crashes frequently to either the BSOD or just shuts off the computer. We have been looking into this and need to find out more to correct this problem.
Hendry
item.content:encoded:
This is a common problem with Transcend Micro Solid State Drives. If you are running your Windows Operating System on one of these drives, you will get a super-fast startup time and application start time.

item.title: By: TomH
item.dc:creator: TomH

item.title: By: Mike
item.dc:creator: Mike
item.description: I put an OCZ 128gb SSD in my desktop as the primary drive and it ran fine for 3 months. However, in the last month I have had numerous system crashes and drive scans continually turn up bad sectors. In 20- years of computing I have never lost data due to a crash until now. After this experience, and all that I have read in the last 24hrs, methinks SSD's are not yet ready for prime time...or at least not ready enough for me I am returning this POS and going back to a tried and true HDD.

item.title: By: Steve
item.dc:creator: Steve
item.description: I have had a 60 GB SSD in my Windows 7 machine for four months and have had to perform numerous system restores and two full reinstalls of Windows 7 Ultimate. Last night in the middle of an HP printer update, the machine froze up. Upon reboot, or should I say attempted reboot, it seems that I it no longer can find the boot manager. I am at the point where I am suspecting the SSD, and am looking to go back to HDD.

item.title: By: Roman Gaufman
item.dc:creator: Roman Gaufman
item.description:
I got my OCZ Vertex Plus 60GB - my test was simple:
1) I took the OCZ SSD and my trusted Crucial M4 SSD 2) I installed the same OS on both (same system, same everything) 3) I tried various scenarios such as pressing reset button when system idle, pulling the power chord out, filling up ram and causing a kernel panic, etc. 4) My Crucial was just fine in all tests, the OCZ Vertex showed severe filesystem corruption, large directories simply missing, etc in all tests - including the system freeze test!
I am sending my OCZ back on Monday.
item.content:encoded:
I got my OCZ Vertex Plus 60GB – my test was simple:

1) I took the OCZ SSD and my trusted Crucial M4 SSD
2) I installed the same OS on both (same system, same everything)
3) I tried various scenarios such as pressing reset button when system idle, pulling the power chord out, filling up ram and causing a kernel panic, etc.
4) My Crucial was just fine in all tests, the OCZ Vertex showed severe filesystem corruption, large directories simply missing, etc in all tests – including the system freeze test!

I am sending my OCZ back on Monday.
